High five for Wentworth as they demolish Langwith

28/10/2012

Wentworth produced a vintage second half performace on 22 Acres today, as the post-graduates put five past Langwith without reply

Image by

By undefined undefined

WENTWORTH 5-0 LANGWITH
Images: Petroc Taylor Wentworth produced a vintage second half performace on 22 Acres today, as the postgraduates put five past Langwith without reply. On a rain-sodden pitch, the match began slowly as both teams struggled to adapt to the difficult conditions and get the ball on the ground. Despite struggling early on, Wentworth began to grow into the game, but no-one could get on the end of a superb through-ball from Nick Townson on the 10-minute mark. As the game began to settle down, Langwith continued to enjoy greater possession, with Andy Hutt holding the ball up well, but his shot from 20 yards went well wide of Jon Cook's post. During a five minute spell of dominance, Langwith had another corner swiftly cleared by the Wentworth defence, and from the subsequent counter-attack, frontman Murray burst through, only to be given offside by the match referee. On 34 minutes Craig Burnell's powerful header sailed over Cook's crossbar, and Langwith were made to rue their missed chances just a minute later, as Dan Bawdon slotted the ball home from inside the area to give Wentworth a fortunate 1-0 lead. Having gone ahead, Wentworth contained an eager Langwith side well. A blistering counter attack saw Dom Green caught offside, before an excellent shot from Townson then had Kris Cheshire scrambling. After the restart, Langwith needed to begin brightly, with a soft penalty shout turned down on 48 minutes - but it was Wentworth that would go on to dominate the remaining proceedings. A speculative shot from frontman Weaver was well-saved by Cheshire, before Tuor tore open the Langwith defence, only to fire straight into the keeper's arms. A sublime ball into the area from Hutt gave Langwith hope on 51 minutes, but Starkey headed just over, before Wentworth doubled their lead two minutes later. Following some good build-up play, Green delivered a neat cross from the right, which was met by Murray to slot the ball into the back of the net. Weaver soon had another header well saved by Cheshire, before distant shots from Hutt and James Hopkin gave Langwith hope of getting back into the tie. However, things went from bad to worse for Langwith. Following a defensive mix-up between Marcus Campbell and Christian Sandmann, Cheshire came running out of his area. With the keeper stranded, the onrushing Green stroked the ball into an empty net to make it 3-0. And any hopes that did remain of a Langwith comeback were completely dashed moments later, after Sandmann was caught in possession inside the area. Weaver was unable to direct the ball past the flailing Cheshire, but Green once again burst into the area on the right hand side and smashed home the rebound to score his second goal in as many minutes. Credit must go a Langwith side which, despite being dishevelled at conceding a double-salvo, did their best to retain possession and create chances; Bruce Starkey worked the ball brilliantly into the area, but was unable to get past a solid Wentworth defence. However, Wentworth hadn't finished yet as Weaver added his name to the scoresheet. Accepting the ball on the edge of the area, the forward lobbed onrushing Cheshire with a peach of a finish to grab the goal of the day- and make the scoreline 5-0. Things almost got even worse for Langwith, as, during a total spell of dominance, Sutton forced an excellent save out of Cheshire. Weaver then had the opportunity to grab his second of the game, but fluffed his lines when one-on-one with the Langwith stopper. There was still time for one last attack from Langwith, gaining some change out of the Wentworth defence, but their second half display was summed up when the subsequent shot from Starkey went out for a Wentworth throw shortly before the full-time whistle. Langwith must be praised for their determination throughout the match, but they were ultimately undone by clinical finishing and not capitalising on their greater possession. For Wentworth, meanwhile, the 5-0 scoreline did not flatter them as a fantastic second-half display ensured their emphatic victory. Langwith's Burnell reflected frankly upon his side's heavy defeat, claiming "We were terrible at times today. Schoolboy errors cost us the game and we didn't capitalise on the possession we had. We had more of the ball than them, and we had more corners too, but we didn't make them count and we've paid a very heavy price for that. We shot ourselves in the foot at the back with some poor mistakes, but I'm sure that we'll be much improved and much more competitive next week against Derwent." Meanwhile, his Wentworth counterpart, Andy Sutton, was delighted with his side's display; "That was fantastic. As far as I'm aware, that's our biggest-ever victory over another firsts side, and it was thoroughly deserved. We were solid defensively, closed them down and dealt with their threats. We allowed them to have more possession but we were strong off the ball. Although we started the game slowly, I feel we really grew into it after about 25 minutes and controlled the game brilliantly - particularly Lachlan (Murray). He was tremendous for us today". Man of the match: Lachlan Murray Langwith: Cheshire, Campbell, Sandmann, Hopkin, Burnell, Starling, Doyle, Hutt, Starkey, Jones, McDonald (Hemingway). Wentworth: Cook, Sellers (Sutton), Clinton, Kosunalp, Townson, Parker, Bawdon, Murray, Dominian (Tuor, (Hill)), Weaver, Green
